Knowledge Point: Any argument or peripheral in a clause can be questioned, as well as its constituents \REF{ex:7:x1167}--\REF{ex:7:x1174}.
Content 1: \gll (\textbf{Mua}) \textbf{naareke} koora ku-am-ika-i-ya? | \gls (man) who.CF house build-SS.SIM-be-Np-3s | \glt  `Who is building a house?'
Content 2: \gll Wi \textbf{kaakew} mua=ke uf-e-mik? | \gls 3p.UNM which.village man=CF dance-PA-1/3p | \glt  `The men of which village danced?'

Knowledge Point: The kind of ambiguity between a subject and an object that Usan has, which arises from the fronting of a topicalized element\footnote{A \textsc{theme} in my terminology here.} \citep[294]{Reesink1987}, is not possible in Mauwake. This is because the question words take the contrastive focus marker \nobreakdash-\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ke} when functioning as a subject. Because of elision, and the merging of the contrastive focus marker with the question word, the word for `who' in Mauwake actually has a contrasted/nominative \REF{ex:7:x1167}, \REF{ex:7:x1171} and an accusative form \REF{ex:7:x1170}. The object is fronted in \REF{ex:7:x1171} as a theme; in \REF{ex:7:x1172} the object is not fronted.
Content 1: \gll (\textbf{Mua}) \textbf{naareke} koora ku-am-ika-i-ya? | \gls (man) who.CF house build-SS.SIM-be-Np-3s | \glt  `Who is building a house?'
Content 2: \gll Mua nain\textsubscript{O} \textbf{naareke}\textsubscript{S} aruf-a-k? | \gls man that1 who.CF hit-PA-3s | \glt  `Who hit that man?'
Content 3: \gll Mua nain\textsubscript{S} \textbf{naarew}\textsubscript{O} aruf-a-k? | \gls man that1 who(ACC) hit-PA-3s | \glt  `Who did that man hit?'
Content 4: \gll Mua nain\textsubscript{O} \textbf{naareke}\textsubscript{S} aruf-a-k? | \gls man that1 who.CF hit-PA-3s | \glt  `Who hit that man?'
Content 5: \gll \textbf{(Mua)} \textbf{naareke}\textsubscript{S} mua nain\textsubscript{O} aruf-a-k? | \gls (man) who.CF man that1 hit-PA-3s | \glt  `Who hit that man?'

Knowledge Point: It is most common to have the question in a main clause, but medial clauses also easily allow non-polar questions. The scope of the question word only extends to the clause which contains it. In \REF{ex:7:x1168} the fact that the people ran away is not questioned.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Mua} \textbf{naareke} \textbf{wia} \textbf{aruf-eya} baurar-e-mik? | \gls man who.CF 3p.ACC hit-2/3s.DS run.away-PA-1/3p | \glt  `Who hit them (so that) they ran away?'

Knowledge Point: A constituent in a complement clause (with a nominalized verb) can be questioned \REF{ex:7:x1175}, but not in a relative clause \REF{ex:7:x1176}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ama} \textbf{kamin} \textbf{ikiw-owa} ma-e-mik? | \gls sun/time how.much go-NMZ say-PA-1/3p | \glt  `At what time did they say to go?'
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Multiple constituents in the same clause can be questioned with a question word. This is not common, but the following elicited sentences are considered completely natural \REF{ex:7:x1177}, \REF{ex:7:x1178}.
Content 1: \gll Emeria \textbf{naareke} ama \textbf{kamin=pa} ekap-o-k? | \gls woman who.CF sun/time how.much=LOC come-PA-3s | \glt  `Who (woman) came at what time?'
Content 2: \gll Mua \textbf{kain=ke} emeria \textbf{kain} aaw-o-k? | \gls man which=CF woman which take-PA-3s | \glt  `Which man took/married which woman?'

Knowledge Point: When there is a lot of hesitation in the question, the question clitic -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{i}, which normally marks a polar question, is added to the end of the question \REF{ex:7:x1187}. This is the same form that the echo questions have (\sectref{sec:7.2.3}).
Content 1: \gll Auwa efa amukar-e-k nain yo \textbf{kamenap} ar-i-nen=\textbf{i}? | \gls father 1s.ACC scold-PA-3s that 1s.UNM how become-Np-FU.1s=QM | \glt  `(I wonder) what will happen to me because father scolded me?'

Knowledge Point: Polar questions , also called nexus questions, or yes-no questions, expect either confirmation or negation of the questioned proposition. According to \citet[63]{Wurm1982}, a polar question in \textstyleAcronymallcaps{tng} languages is often marked by an affix which is part of the verb complex. In Mauwake it is coded by the question clitic -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{i} (\sectref{sec:3.12.8}) and slightly rising intonation (\sectref{sec:2.1.3.2}), both occurring sentence-finally. Because Mauwake is an \textstyleAcronymallcaps{sov} language, the clitic most often attaches itself to a verb \REF{ex:7:x1179}, but it can attach to another word class as well, when there is no final verb \REF{ex:7:x1180}, \REF{ex:7:x1181}:
Content 1: \gll Ni nain me=ko uruf-a-man\textbf{=i}? | \gls 2p.UNM that1 not=NF see-PA-2p=QM | \glt  `Didn't you see that?'
Content 2: \gll Nos=\textbf{i}? | \gls 2s.FC=QM | \glt  `You?'
Content 3: \gll Maa nain eliwa=\textbf{ki}? | \gls thing that1 good=CF.QM | \glt  `Is that thing good?'

Knowledge Point: The non-final alternatives in a closed question take the question marker -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{i}. The final alternative, usually preceded by the disjunctive coordinator \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{e} `or' (\sectref{sec:3.11.2}), may be just a negation particle \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{weetak} or \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wia} \REF{ex:7:x1182}, a full statement \REF{ex:7:x1183}, or an elliptical clause with only the questioned item \REF{ex:7:x1184}.
Content 1: \gll Yo emeria=ko efar uruf-a-man=\textbf{i} \textbf{e} weetak? | \gls 1s.UNM woman=NF 1s.DAT see-PA-2p=QM or no | \glt  `Did you see my wife or not?'
Content 2: \gll Nain kema suuw-i-man=\textbf{i} \textbf{e} kema irin-ar-e-man? | \gls that1 liver push-Np-PR.2p=QM or liver stuck-INCH-PA-2p | \glt  `Do you remember (lit: push the liver) that, or have you forgotten (lit: liver is stuck) it?'
Content 3: \gll No Matukar ikiw-i-nan=\textbf{i} Dylup=\textbf{i} \textbf{e} Sarang? | \gls 2s.UNM Matukar go-Np-FU.2s=QM Dylup=QM or Sarang | \glt  `Will you go to Matukar, Dylup, or Sarang?'

Knowledge Point: When the alternative question is open, the question marker -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{i} marks not only the non-final alternatives but also the final one \REF{ex:7:x1185}, \REF{ex:7:x1186}.
Content 1: \gll Matukar ikiw-i-nan=\textbf{i} \textbf{e} Dylup ikiw-i-nan=\textbf{i}? | \gls Matukar go-Np-FU.2s=QM or Dylup go-Np-FU.2s=QM | \glt  `Will you go to Matukar or Dylup (or perhaps neither)?'
Content 2: \gll Mukuna=ko wu-a-man=\textbf{i} \textbf{e} mua=ko wia uruf-a-man=\textbf{i}? | \gls fire=NF put-PA-2p=QM or man=NF 3.ACC see-PA-2p=QM | \glt  `Did you light a fire or did you feel (that there was) a man?'

Knowledge Point: An alternative question is left open also when the last alternative is replaced with the question word \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kamenion} '(or) what?'/ `(or) how is it?' \REF{ex:7:x1350}, \REF{ex:7:x1351}.
Content 1: \gll Maa en-owa=ko p-ekap-e-mik=\textbf{i} \textbf{kamenion}? | \gls food eat-NMZ=NF BPX-come-PA-1/3p=QM or.what | \glt  `Did they bring food, or what?'
Content 2: \gll Beel(a)-al-i-non=\textbf{i} \textbf{kamenion}, naap uruf-am-ik-ua. | \gls rotten-INCH-Np-FU.3s=QM or.what thus see-SS.SIM-be-PA.3s | \glt  `He was watching whether it would rot or what would happen.'

Knowledge Point: Leading questions are another subtype of polar questions. The person asking wants to guide the answer in a certain direction. This is done in Mauwake by adding the epistemic modal adverb clitic -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{yon} `perhaps' to the predicate of the question clause. The slightly rising intonation in the question distinguishes it from a statement \REF{ex:7:x1349}.
Content 1: \gll Me ikiw-o-k=\textbf{yon}? | \gls not go-PA-3s-perhaps | \glt  `He didn't go, did he?'

Knowledge Point: Echo question of a \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{statement}} is like a normal polar question, except that the questioned element receives an extra stress \REF{ex:7:x1189}.
Content 1: \gll A:Paapa Goroka ikiw-i-non. - B: Gor\'oka ikiw-i-non=i? | \gls A:elder.sibling Goroka go-Np-FU.3p - B: Goroka go-Np-FU.3p=QM | \glt  `A: Big brother is going to Goroka. B: Is he going to \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{Goroka}}?'

Knowledge Point: When the validity of a \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{non-polar question}} \REF{ex:7:x1190} is questioned, the question clitic is attached directly to the end of the question already containing a question word \REF{ex:7:x1191}.
Content 1: \gll A: Mua naarew wia maak-e-k? | \gls A: man who 3.ACC tell-PA-3s | \glt  `Who did he tell?'
Content 2: \gll B: Mua naarew wia maak-e-k=\textbf{i}? | \gls B: man who 3.ACC tell-PA-3s=QM | \glt  `Who did he tell???'

Knowledge Point: But if the addressee wants to check if (s)he heard correctly, the echoed question is made into a complement of a sentence-final utterance verb, to which a question clitic is attached \REF{ex:7:x1192}.
Content 1: \gll B: Mua naarew wia maak-e-k \textbf{na-i-n=i}? | \gls B: man who 3.ACC tell-PA-3s say-Np-PR.2s=QM | \glt  `Are you asking who he told?'

Knowledge Point: Since \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{polar questions}} already have a clause-final question clitic, an echo question cannot be formed by adding the same clitic a second time. Instead, the original question is made into a complement of the utterance verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ma}- `say' or \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{na}- `say/think' \REF{ex:7:x1193}.
Content 1: \gll A: Nain eliwa=ki? B: Nain eliwa-ki \textbf{ma-e-n=i}? | \gls A: that1 good=CF.QM B: that1 good=CF.QM say-PA-2s=QM | \glt  `A: Is that good? B: Did you ask if that is good?'

Knowledge Point: Confirmation questions are mainly used in argumentation. The question word \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naap}\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{-i} `(is it) like that?' is tagged to a statement, which may be preceded by another question \REF{ex:7:x1188}.
Content 1: \gll Ni kema maneka naap efa wu-i-man=i, yo eliw nia saliw-i-nen, \textbf{naap=i}? | \gls 2p.UNM liver big thus 1s.ACC put-Np-PR.2p=QM 1s.UNM well 2p.ACC heal-Np-FU.1s thus=QM | \glt  `Do you believe about me that I can heal you, is that so?'

Knowledge Point: Indirect questions \REF{ex:7:x1203}, \REF{ex:7:x1204} are a subgroup of complement clauses and are discussed under \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{Indirect speech}} in \sectref{sec:8.3.2.1.2}.
Content 1: \gll Yo maa mauwa uruf-a-m efa na-e-k. | \gls 1s.UNM thing what see-PA-1s 1s.ACC say-PA-3s | \glt  `He asked me what I saw.'
Content 2: \gll Kamin wu-a-mik(-yon), yo me wiar amis-ar-e-m. | \gls how.much put-PA-1/3p-perhaps 1s.UNM not 3.DAT knowledge-INCH-PA-1s | \glt  `I don't know how much they put.'

Knowledge Point: Traditionally the Mauwake speakers lived in a society where everyone more or less knew everybody's business and there was not much need for eliciting information by asking questions. Consequently, many questions in normal speech are rhetorical in nature. The question form may be used to emphasize the opposite of what is said \REF{ex:7:x1205}, \REF{ex:7:x1206} or sometimes just to prompt the addressee to think more clearly, but very often rhetorical questions have an element of reproach or assigning blame as well \REF{ex:7:x1202}, \REF{ex:7:x1207}.
Content 1: \gll Maamuma kaaneke ika-eya ni-i-yan? | \gls money where.CF be-2/3s.DS give.you-Np-FU.1p | \glt  `Where would we have that kind of money to give you? (=We do not have money to give you.)'
Content 2: \gll Yo anane niam=iya ika-i-nen=i? | \gls 1s.UNM always 2p.REFL=COM be-Np-FU.1s=QM | \glt  `Will I be with you forever? (= I will not.)'
Content 3: \gll No moram naap om-em-ika-i-n? | \gls 2s.UNM why thus cry-SS.SIM-be-Np-PR.2s | \glt  `Why are you crying like that? (=You should not cry like that.)'
Content 4: \gll Mua naareke nia maak-eya ekap-e-man? | \gls man who.CF 2p.ACC say-2/3p.DS come-PA-2p | \glt  `Who told you to come? (=You shouldn't have come)'

Knowledge Point: Implied reproach or accusation is particularly common with questions including the word \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{moram} `why?' \REF{ex:7:x1208}, but it is not limited to them. Especially accusations of theft are couched in neutral-looking questions \REF{ex:7:x1209}.
Content 1: \gll Aa muuka, no moram naap yia on-a-n? | \gls oh son 2s.UNM why thus 1s.ACC do-PA-2s | \glt  `Oh son, why did you do this to us?'
Content 2: \gll Yo seewa gelemuta uruma or-o-k nain uruf-a-man=i? | \gls 1s.UNM rat small valley descend-PA-3s that1 see-PA-2p=QM | \glt  `Have you seen my ``little rat'' (pig) that went down to the valley? (implying: I have no doubt that you have stolen my pig.)'

Knowledge Point: Because questions are so easily understood as reproaches or accusations, real questions are often preceded by a preamble to prevent this interpretation \REF{ex:7:x1210}--\REF{ex:7:x1355}.
Content 1: \gll Ama arow=pa mauw-owa weeser-eya maa mauwa on-a-man? | \gls sun three=LOC work-NMZ finish-2/3s.DS thing what do-PA-2p | \glt  `After your work finished at three, what did you do?'
Content 2: \gll Anane maneka ewur me urup-i-n nain moram? | \gls always big quickly not ascend-Np-PR.2s that1 why | \glt  `What is the reason why you never come up quickly?'

Knowledge Point: Apart from rhetorical questions, a verbal answer is often expected. An affirmative answer to a polar question \REF{ex:7:x1216} may be just an affirmative interjection \REF{ex:7:x1217} or the verb from the question by itself or preceded by the interjection \REF{ex:7:x1218}. A negative answer must have at least one negator (\sectref{sec:6.2}), whether only a negative interjection (\sectref{sec:6.2.3}), or any of the other negators, or both \REF{ex:7:x1220}. Less commonly the answer may also be a full statement with or without a preceding affirmation \REF{ex:7:x1219} or negation.
Content 1: \gll No uurika owow maneka ikiw-i-nan=i? | \gls 2s.UNM tomorrow village big go-Np-FU.2s=QM | \glt  `Are you going to town tomorrow?'
Content 2: \gll Ae/Oo. | \gls yes | \glt  `Yes.'
Content 3: \gll (Ae,) ikiw-i-nen. | \gls yes go-Np-FU.1s | \glt  `(Yes,) I am going.'
Content 4: \gll (Weetak,) me ikiw-i-nen. | \gls no not go-Np-FU.1s | \glt  `(No,) I am not going.'
Content 5: \gll (Ae,) yo uurika owow maneka ikiw-i-nen. | \gls yes 1s.UNM tomorrow village big go-Np-FU.1s | \glt  `(Yes,) I'll go to town tomorrow.'

Knowledge Point: The reply to a non-polar question most typically includes an answer to the questioned item and often the verb of the original question too \REF{ex:7:x1221}--\REF{ex:7:x1222}.
Content 1: \gll Maa sira kamenap nain en-em-ik-e-man? | \gls thing/food kind how that1 eat-SS.SIM-be-PA-2p | \glt  `What kind of food did you eat?'
Content 2: \gll Wi mia kia en-owa nain (en-em-ik-e-mik). | \gls 3p.UNM body white eat-NMZ that1 (eat-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p) | \glt  `(We ate) the white people's food.'

Knowledge Point: If the speaker wants to negate the presupposition in the question \REF{ex:7:x1223}, (s)he begins with a negator, and then goes on to answer the question itself \REF{ex:7:x1224}.
Content 1: \gll Neremena kamenap nefa on-a-k? | \gls 2s/p.nephew how 2s.ACC do-PA-3s | \glt  `What did your nephew do to you?'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Weetak}, yo mauw-a-m ne o me efa uruf-a-k. | \gls no 1s.UNM work-PA-1s ADD 3s.UNM not 1s.ACC see-PA-3s | \glt  `I worked but he did not even look at me.' (Implying: Your presupposition is wrong; he did not do anything indecent to me.)

Knowledge Point: If the question or statement itself is negative, a one-word answer is ambiguous in present-day usage, and a full clause is needed to disambiguate it \REF{ex:7:x1151}. Traditionally an answer to a question affirmed or negated the affirmative or negative \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{polarity}} of the question or statement \REF{ex:7:x1117}.
Content 1: \gll O aakun-owa marew=yon. -\textbf{Wia}, aakun-owa wiar ik-ua. | \gls 3s.UNM talk-NMZ no(ne)-perhaps -no talk-NMZ 3.DAT be-PA.3s | \glt  `Perhaps he doesn't have anything to say. --No, he \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{does}} have something to say.'
Content 2: \gll Auwa me ekap-o-k=i? -\textbf{Weetak} (ekap-o-k). | \gls 1s/p.father not come-PA-3s=QM -no (come-PA-3s) | \glt  `Didn't father come? --Yes (he \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{did}}).'

Knowledge Point: But Mauwake is changing to become more like English in that the negative answer stands for a negative statement regardless of the polarity of the question or statement that it is a reply to \REF{ex:7:x1118}:\footnote{A similar change is taking place in Tok Pisin, and it is likely that this is causing the development in Mauwake too.}
Content 1: \gll Auwa me ekap-o-k=i? -\textbf{Weetak} (me ekap-o-k). | \gls 1s/p.father not come-PA-3s=QM -no (not come-PA-3s) | \glt  `Didn't father come? --No (he didn't).'

Knowledge Point: The simple imperative is the default way of expressing a command in Mauwake. It shows in the verb inflection \REF{ex:7:x1072} (\sectref{sec:3.8.3.3.2}). In a prohibition the verbal negator \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{me} `not' precedes the simple imperative \REF{ex:7:x1075}.
Content 1: \gll Ni Medebur \textbf{karu-eka}, \textbf{baurar-eka}. | \gls 2p.UNM Medebur run-IMP.2p flee-IMP.2p | \glt  `Run(pl.) to Medebur, flee.'
Content 2: \gll Momora, no naap \textbf{me} \textbf{ma-e}. | \gls fool 2s.UNM thus not say-IMP.2s | \glt  `Fool, don't say like that.'

Knowledge Point: The simple imperative can be strengthened with the intensity adverb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{akena} `very, truly' following the verb \REF{ex:7:x1073}.
Content 1: \gll Ni sira samora \textbf{piipu-eka akena}. | \gls 2p.UNM habit bad leave-IMP.2p truly | \glt  `Really get rid of your bad habits.'

Knowledge Point: Another way to intensify it is with the clause-final interjection \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nom} `\textstyleEmphasizedWords{{please}}!', which is only used when a person has already been told to do something at least once and has not complied \REF{ex:7:x1074}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Pootin-e}, \textbf{nom}! | \gls stop.crying-IMP.2s please | \glt  `Stop crying, \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{please}}!'

Knowledge Point: The imperative marking on verbs shows only in the finite forms. When a command or request is in a medial clause, and the final clause verb is in the indicative mood and future tense, there is nothing in the medial verb to indicate the mood \REF{ex:7:x1076}.
Content 1: \gll No opaimika pon aaw-o-n nain \textbf{ma-eya} i miim-i-yen. | \gls 2s.UNM talk turtle get-PA-3s that1 tell-2/3s.DS 1p.UNM hear-Np-FU.1p | \glt  `Tell us about your catching a turtle, and we'll listen.' (Or: `You will tell us about your catching a turtle and we'll listen.')

Knowledge Point: This type of clause combination has given rise to a softer, less direct command, which is given with a medial different-subject form of a verb; the final clause is left out altogether \REF{ex:7:x1084}.\footnote{This fairly common use of a medial verb form in Papuan languages is probably the origin of the use of pastaim `first' in Tok Pisin commands, e.g. Kam pastaim `Come!'} This form is particularly common when commands are given to children.
Content 1: \gll P-ekap-\textbf{eya}! | \gls BPX-come-2/3s.DS | \glt  `Bring it!'

Knowledge Point: The imperative of the final clause may have an influence on the medial clause(s) so that they are also interpreted as belonging within the scope of the command. This happens very easily with same-subject medial verbs \REF{ex:7:x1082}; it is also possible but much less likely when the subject changes \REF{ex:7:x1364}.\footnote{This example may also be interpreted to have two commands: a ``soft'' one, expressed with a medial verb, and a regular one.} Example \REF{ex:7:x1846} is ambiguous: in the situation where it was said, the medial clause was not in the scope of the final clause imperative; in some other situation it could be. When the medial verb has a first person form, imperative interpretation is not possible \REF{ex:7:x1083}.
Content 1: \gll Emeria manina \textbf{ikiw-ep} en-owa \textbf{nop-ap} \textbf{or-eka}. | \gls woman garden go-SS.SEQ eat-NMZ search-SS.SEQ descend-IMP.2p | \glt  `Women, go to the garden, look for food and come down.'
Content 2: \gll Mua emeria wia \textbf{maak-eya} me efa \textbf{enim-uk}. | \gls man woman 3p.ACC tell-2/3s.DS not 2s.ACC eat-IMP.3p | \glt  `Tell the people and let them not eat me.'
Content 3: \gll Feeke wiar \textbf{ik-ok} kiiriw mua wiar \textbf{urup-e}. | \gls here.CF 3.DAT be-SS again man 3.DAT ascend-IMP.2s | \glt  `Having been here with him (=your brother), go up to your husband again.'

Knowledge Point: Although a command is usually directed towards one or more people in the second person, it can also be directed towards the speaker as part of a group of two \REF{ex:7:x1157} or more \REF{ex:7:x1158}, or towards a third person in singular \REF{ex:7:x1159} or plural \REF{ex:7:x1160}.
Content 1: \gll Aria, i owowa=ko \textbf{or-u}. | \gls alright 1p.UNM village=NF descend-IMP.1d | \glt  `Alright, let's go down to the village.'
Content 2: \gll Ikiw-ep=ko wia \textbf{uruf-ikua}. | \gls go-SS.SEQ=NF 3p.ACC see-IMP.1p | \glt  `Let's go and see them.'
Content 3: \gll Womokowa me wia \textbf{maak-inok}. | \gls 3s/p.brother not 3p.ACC tell-IMP.3s | \glt  `Let her not talk to her brothers.'
Content 4: \gll Ona mua owawiya ek-ap uruf-am-ik-ok \textbf{ep-am-ika-uk.} | \gls 3s.GEN man with go-SS.SEQ see-SS.SIM-be-SS come-SS.SIM-be-IMP.3p | \glt  `Let her keep going with her husband, seeing him (= her father) and coming back.'

Knowledge Point: Imperatives cannot have tense distinctions, but aspectual distinctions are possible. The continuous aspect form is used for habitual aspect in \REF{ex:7:x1160} above, and for continuous aspect in \REF{ex:7:x1896}. Completive aspect is used in \REF{ex:7:x1161} and stative aspect in \REF{ex:7:x1162}.
Content 1: \gll Ona mua owawiya ek-ap uruf-am-ik-ok \textbf{ep-am-ika-uk.} | \gls 3s.GEN man with go-SS.SEQ see-SS.SIM-be-SS come-SS.SIM-be-IMP.3p | \glt  `Let her keep going with her husband, seeing him (= her father) and coming back.'
Content 2: \gll Sira naap \textbf{on-am-ik-eka}. | \gls custom thus do-SS.SIM-be-IMP.2p | \glt  `Keep doing like that.'
Content 3: \gll Aakisa naap \textbf{on-ap-pu-e}. | \gls now thus do-SS.SEQ-CMPL-IMP.2s | \glt  `Now do that.'
Content 4: \gll No me mokoka \textbf{opar-ep-ik-e}. | \gls 2s.UNM not eye close-SS.SEQ-be-IMP.2s | \glt  `Don't have/keep your eyes closed.'

Knowledge Point: The second person future tense form is also used for a command, but this is not very common. It is used in a specific situation, not for giving generic commands or rules. The sentence \REF{ex:7:x1080} was said to a person who was suspected of lying, and in \REF{ex:7:x1081} parents give instructions to their daughter how to mourn.
Content 1: \gll No \textbf{me} \textbf{sail-i-nan}! | \gls 2s.UNM not lie-Np-FU.2s | \glt  `Don't lie!'
Content 2: \gll Naap ma-emi \textbf{om-em-ika-i-nan} na. | \gls thus say-SS.SIM cry-SS.SIM-be-Np-FU.2s INTJ | \glt  `Say like that and wail.'
